locals: Optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations
notes: Infarction of the distal anterior choroidal artery can cause quadruple sectoranopia, a characteristic visual field defect associated with sectorial optic atrophy. Occlusion of the anterior choroidal artery during tumor removal led to partial infarction of the lateral geniculate nucleus, causing the visual field defect. The distribution of retinal nerve fiber atrophy corresponds to the infarcted area of the lateral geniculate nucleus (Frisén, 1979).
local_name: Optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations

arteries: Bilateral Middle cerebral artery - posterior parietal and angular
notes: Ischemia is the most common cause of Bálint's syndrome, particularly from watershed infarctions. Optic ataxia is a difficulty in initiating saccades to visual targets on command, although patients may easily make spontaneous scanning saccades or reflex saccades to suddenly appearing stimuli.

Benedikt's is essentially Weber's + Claude's. Because the fascicles of cranial nerve (CN) III are scattered in their course through the midbrain, the third nerve palsy in any of these syndromes may be partial.

Benedikt syndrome is an extremely rare eponymous cluster of symptoms due to anatomically specific midbrain damage. It is characterized by ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, and contralateral cerebellar ataxia, Holmes tremor, or choreoathetosis.

Pierce Burr, Kesava Mandalaneni. Benedikt Syndrome. In: StatPearls. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Last Update: July 4, 2023.

arteries: Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) - bilateral (azygous distal ACA)

signs: Prosopagnosia (inability to recognize previously familiar faces)

notes:
If present, a palsy of CN VI is heralded by complaints of diplopia and findings of restricted abduction ipsilateral to the lesion. Hemiparesis of the arms and legs contralateral to the lesion is present. A Babinski sign may be present on the affected side. Typically, but not invariably,[1] sensation in the face and the extremities is unaffected in MGS. 

[1] Source: Patel S, Bhakta A, Wortsman J, Aryal BB, Shrestha DB, Joshi T. Pontine Infarct Resulting in Millard-Gubler Syndrome: A Case Report. Cureus. 2023 Feb;15(2):e34869.

arteries: Heubners artery or perforating branches from A1

locals: Caudate nucleus, putamen, anterior portion of internal capsule
arteries: Heubners artery or perforating branches from A1

locals: Head of caudate nucleus, putamen, anterior portion of internal capsule
notes: Lesions of the putamen and GP often resulted in dystonia, particularly with putaminal involvement.
Facial palsy: It is presumably caused by involvement of aberrant corticobulbar fibers that loop caudally before travelling rostrally toward the facial nucleus
In a series describing small infarcts limited to the nodule, 310 all patients presented with isolated vertigo, unilateral ipsilesional nystagmus, and falling to the opposite direction
Frequently, accompanied by anomia and Gerstmann syndrome
Usually, alexia in Left Temporal lobe (angular gyrus) is accompanied by agraphia

locals: Left Temporal lobe (fusiform) AND callosal fibers at the splenium
Left Temporal lobe (more anterior segments of fusiform gyri)
notes: In apperceptive visual agnosia, the individual does not recognize what the object is, does not discern its forms (the percept). In associative visual agnosia, he perceives the form but does not recognize what the object is.

locals: Left temporooccipital lobe (frequent extension to callosal interhemispheric fibers)
notes: Optic aphasia is typically a visuoverbal disconnection syndrome. Difficulty naming objects by sight, but does so through other non-visual stimuli and can describe their use, including pantomime.
Gait instability or body lateropulsion may be related to involvement of the vestibulocerebellar tract, inferior olivary nucleus, or more laterally located spinocerebellar tract
Lateropulsion in this case is contralateral to the lesions side
Unlike pontine infarction, the face is mostly spared because the lesions are below the level of the facial nerve nucleus/fascicles
In lesions of medial medulla, sensory loss is the 2nd most important symptom/sign;
Motor neglect: These individuals have little voluntary movement on the hemiparetic side
In PICA infarction, headache is usually unilateral in cervical,occipital or both regions.
Lateropulsion is a striking sign in PICA territory infarction.
In PICA infarction, horizontal nystagmus is more common than vertical ones, unilateral and ipsilesional. Head impulse is usually normal.

In PICA infarction (partial territory), the vertigo may be aggravated (or relieved) on certain head positions and patients may describe recurrent vertigo symptoms. In cerebellum, it is caused by involvement of uvulonodular complex of the vermis

In humans, cerebellar areas around the vermis appear to be involved in the formation of fear memory traces. 301 One of the authors (JSK) observed patients who showed phobic attacks after cerebellar infarction. In clinical practice, however, emotional incontinence (excessive or inappropriate laughing/crying) is much more frequently observed
An anterolateral lesion is the second most common pattern (25%) of pure midbrain infarction. Hemiparesis is the classic sign and it is due to crus cerebri involvement.

Claudeâ€™s syndrome is caused by infarction of the third nerve nucleus or its fibers and of the cerebellothalamic connections when they pass through the red nucleus. The combination of a third nerve palsy with contralateral involuntary abnormal movements like dystonia, parkinsonism, resting and postural tremor, or chorea affecting the contralateral limbs is known as Benediktâ€™s syndrome.

Claudeâ€™s syndrome is caused by infarction of the third nerve nucleus or its fibers and of the cerebellothalamic connections when they pass through the red nucleus. The combination of a third nerve palsy with contralateral involuntary abnormal movements like dystonia, parkinsonism, resting and postural tremor, or chorea affecting the contralateral limbs is known as Benediktâ€™s syndrome.
An anteromedial (paramedian) lesion is the most common pattern (50-60% of pure midbrain infarctions)
Oculomotor palsies are frequent in midbrain strokes and dominate the neurological picture; they provide the best indication of a lesion affecting the midbrain.

WEBER SYNDROME: Contralateral parkinsonism occurs because the substantia nigra's dopaminergic projections to the basal ganglia affect the contralateral body. Contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia results from corticospinal tract lesions before medullary decussation. Corticobulbar tract damage causes contralateral lower facial muscle and hypoglossal nerve dysfunction. Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy presents with partial ptosis, mydriasis, and diplopia. 

Munakomi S, Das JM. Weber Syndrome. In: StatPearls. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; August 13, 2023.

Third nerve palsy plus hemiplegia Herman Weber [9] described a patient who presented with unilateral third nerve palsy associated with a crossed hemiplegia due to a hematoma affecting the paramedian and lateral midbrain. Infarcts as causes of Weberâ€™s syndrome are rare.
In midbrain (anteromedial), sensory deficits, when present, are usually mild and often present in restricted body parts such as the perioral or perioral-hand areas.

Infarcts occurring in midbrain (dorsolateral) are almost always accompanied by concomitant involvement of the cerebellum. Because the lesions mostly damage the trochlear nucleus or the fascicle before decussation, superior oblique palsy usually develops in the eye contralateral to the midbrain stroke
Midbrain (lateral) only is very uncommon: sensory symptoms due to involvement of the laterally located sensory lemniscus
6th and 7th nerve palsies with contralateral hemiparesis is refered to Millard-Gubler syndrome

Nothnagel's (ophthalmoplegia-ataxia) syndrome is different; it is more a variant of Parinaud's syndrome, with unilateral or bilateral third nerve palsy and ataxia accompanied by vertical gaze deficits and other neurologic signs. The lesion affects the midbrain tectum and is often neoplastic.

The pattern and severity of visual field defect may vary according to the lesion location and extension, which is in part related to the status of collateral flows (e.g., flows from the MCA); patients may have macula sparing or isolated central hemianopia (infarction is confined to the occipital pole).
In polyopia, micropsia, macropsia and metamorphopsia, most patients have visual field defects.

In patients with PCA infarction, visual hallucination is uncommon and tends to occur more in the recovery phase than the acute stage. Most patients are aware that the hallucinations are not real and do not feel that they are threatening.

notes: Temporal lobe involvement can cause an agitated and confused state.

locals: Bilateral Thalamus (Intralaminar and Medial Dorsal nuclei)
arteries: Percheron artery (single pedicle from P1 originating bilateral paramedian arteries)

notes: Pons (basal paramedian) is the most common pattern of stroke; a medially located lesion preferentially affects the face and arm, causing a cheiro-oral syndrome
Emotional disturbances in pontine infarction are usually pathologic laughing or crying
In basilar occlusion and hemiparesis, frequently there are abnormal movements (shivering, twitching, shaking, or jerking) of the relatively spared side
When all voluntary movements are lost, the deficit is referred to as the "locked-in" syndrome. Vertical eye movements are usually spared and are used for simple communications

definition of ocular bobbing: the eyeballs intermittently dip briskly downward through an arc of a few millimeters and then return to the primary position in a kind of bobbing action (Fisher's definition). Ocular bobbing is an ominous sign, usually associated with extensive, bilateral pontine infarcts or hemorrhages

Usually palatal myoclonus have a delayed onset and happens when "Guillain-Mollaret triangle" is affected, which includes the dentate nucleus of the cerebellum, the red nucleus in the midbrain, and the inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla and their interconnections
In pontine infarction, trigeminal sensory symptoms may be restricted to the intraoral area.
Frequently infarction of Pons (dorsolateral) is accompanied by cerebellar infarction
Hemiparesis is rare in infarction of Pons (dorsolateral) or is mild
Frequently infarction of Pons (dorsolateral) is accompanied by cerebellar infarction; laterally located lesions produce leg-dominant sensory symptoms.
Frequently infarction of Pons (dorsolateral) is accompanied by cerebellar infarction
Hemiparesis is rare in infarction of Pons (dorsolateral) or is mild
Involvement of Pons (tegmental paramedian) is second most common pattern of pure pontine infarction
Involvement of Pons (tegmental paramedian) is second most common pattern of pure pontine infarction; 6th nerve and fascicles are located in Pons (tegmental paramedian lower pons)
Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) due to involvement of the MLF is much more common in patients with pontine infarction than 6th nerve palsy
In pontine involvement: medially located lesion preferentially affects the face and arm, causing a cheiro-oral syndrome, whereas laterally located lesions produce leg-dominant sensory symptom

locals: Thalamus (Lateral Geniculate Body, Pulvinar, Lateral Dorsal and Lateral Posterior nuclei)
Optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations
notes: Infarction limited to posterior choroidal artery territory area is uncommon and accounts for 9.5% of thalamic infarcts. The fact that the anterior choroidal artery supplies a part of the LGB may explain the diverse pattern of visual field defects in patients with posterior choroidal artery infarction.

In thalamic infaction, impaired fast-phase optokinetic response to the opposite side of the lesion has also been observed, which could be attributed to the involvement of the smooth pursuit pathways in the LGB

Infarction of the lateral posterior choroidal artery (LPChA) region typically results in a distinctive visual field defect known as a homonymous horizontal sectoranopia or a wedge-shaped defect. This occurs because the LPChA supplies the intermediate portion of the lateral geniculate body (LGB), which receives input from the horizontal sector of the visual field. While homonymous horizontal sectoranopia is considered the hallmark of LPChA region infarction, a complete homonymous hemianopsia can also occur when the entire LGB is compromised. Therefore, in cases of homonymous hemianopsia, the possibility of an LGB lesion due to LPChA region infarction should be considered in the differential diagnosis.

Shibata, K., Nishimura, Y., Kondo, H., Otuka, K., & Iwata, M. (2009). Isolated homonymous hemianopsia due to lateral posterior choroidal artery region infarction: A case report. Clinical Neurology and Neurosurgery, 111(8), 713-716. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.clineuro.2009.07.003

There is a type of topographagnosia in which landmarks are "recognized" but do not evoke a sense of direction (i.e., directional or heading disorientation). The patient fails to utilize previously learned routes when traveling from one landmark to another.

signs: Prosopagnosia (inability to recognize previously familiar faces)

locals: Right Temporal lobe (parahippocampal and anterior of lingual and fusiform gyri)
notes: In temporal disorientation, in addition to the usual causes (delirium, etc.) it is important to determine whether the patient recognizes landmarks.

locals: Right Thalamus (Lateral Geniculate Body, Pulvinar, Lateral Dorsal and Lateral Posterior nuclei)

notes: Abnormal movements in SCA territory infarction: due lesion to dentate nucleus or the superior cerebellar peduncle

Dysarthria in SCA territory infarction is characterized by irregularly distributed articulatory deficits, monotonous and scanning speech, and is localized to the paravermal segments of the rostral cerebellar hemisphere

Patients with severe apperceptive agnosia usually have extensive and diffuse occipital lesions and tend to have residual field defects.

notes: In cheiro-oral syndrome due to thalamic involvement, the thumb and index finger are preferentially or selectively involved.

Inferolateral (thalamogeniculate) arteries are composed of 5–10 arteries that arise from the P2 portion of the PCA. Inferolateral artery territory infarction is the most common type of thalamic infarction

notes: Involvement of the paramedian (Thalamic-Subthalamic) territory is very common in patients with occlusion of the top of BA (top of the BA syndrome. Other commonly involved structures include the occipital lobe, cerebellum, and brainstem

After thalamic strokes, depending on intrathalamic infarct location, other behavioral changes can be observed, such as euphoria or mania. Involuntary emotional expression disorder Uncontrollable outbursts of laughing, crying, or both are frequent findings in patients with subcortical lesions, particularly in left or bilateral lesions. These outbursts have a paroxysmal onset, transient duration of seconds or minutes, are stereotyped, incongruent, or exaggerated, relative to the emotional feeling, are precipitated by nonspecific or inappropriate stimuli but also by appropriate stimuli, and occur even in an inappropriate context

notes: The SCAs divide into medial and lateral branches (mSCA and lSCA) and supply the superior half of the cerebellar hemispheres and vermis as well as the dentate nucleus.

Raymond syndrome is a posterior circulatory stroke syndrome due to a lesion in the ventral medial mid-pons. Classic Raymond syndrome consists of ipsilateral abducens impairment, contralateral central facial paresis, and contralateral hemiparesis. Raymond syndrome was first described in 1895 by Fulgence Raymond.
Caused by lesions in the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncles, located in the caudal paramedian midbrain, ventral to the cerebral aqueduct
